text_description: Stone tools are used for hunting and gathering, as well as to create tools out of bamboo, rattan, and wood.
Pottery with red slips which are painted, impressed, incised, excised, and appliqued, are used in central Philippines, Cagayan Valley, and Palawan.
Jewelry consisting of two shell discs and a perforated disc made from a cone shell are used, as evidenced by findings in Duyong Cave, Palawan (2680 BCE).

media_caption: Turnsout, the 127 stylized human and animal figures (frogs and lizards) engraved on the rockwall dated back to 3000 BC. Along with other designs that may have depicted other interesting figures, erosion may have caused it to deteriorate.
text_description: Angono petroglyphs are carved on Rizal cave walls, first reported by Carlos Botong Francisco (1912-1969) in 1965. (Photo from Wikimedia Commons)
The Sa-hyunh Kalanay pottery tradition develops in Southern Philippines after 2000 BC.
The Novaliches pottery tradition flourishes in northwest Palawan and the Calamianes Islands; it is dated from 250 BC to the 4th century.
The Bau-Malay tradition or geometric pottery of south China is found in coastal sites in Mindanao, Bohol, northern Palawan, and the Calamianes Island; it is dated to the 10th century.

Indigenous art forms such as textile-making, mat weaving, wood carving, and brass casting are nuanced by the Islamic preference for geometric and floral designs. Motifs such as the okir, sarimanok, burqa and batik designs are considered as Muslim art which fuses Islamic beliefs, Hindu-Malay cultural traditions, and indigenous world view and beliefs.
Brass casting in the Philippines before the 15th century supposedly begins in Sulu, creating blades such as the parang with excellent craftsmanship.
The Santo Nino de Cebu, a sculptural image of the Infant Jesus, is gifted by Magellan to Hara Amihan, the wife of Rajah Humabon. She is baptized with the Christian name, Juana.

article_title: VA 1565 de Legazpi and Santo Niño
text_description: Miguel Lopez de Legazpi finds the Santo Nino de Cebu in native attire. The veneration of the image through various performative rituals begins. In the future, the belief and rituals about the image are integrated into the production of festivals employing exotic costumes.

Religious art forms are crafted for the Catholic church, for the purpose of conversion of the native population. Chinese artisans are conscripted to create paintings, engravings, sculptures, vestments, furniture, and church decorations.
Azulejos or tiles, ivory carvings, and capiz are exported to Mexico.
The artifacts excavated from the San Diego in 1992 by archaeologists, include pottery and ceramics, jewelry, coins, armaments and other trade goods, all in use in 1600.
1606: The image of the Black Nazarene, aka Poong Itim na Nazareno, which was crafted in Mexico, is brought to the Philippines by the Augustinian Recollects through the galleon.
1617: The Spanish plateresque retablo of San Agustin Church in Intramuros, said to be the earliest retablo of that church, is carved by Juan de los Santos.
Santa Catalina, a beaterio, is founded. In the 19th century; the nuns of Santa Catalina will teach embroidery to their students.
Sculptures in the form of caryatids are seen in some bahay na bato ancestral houses in Bulacan and Escolta.

media_caption: Copy of the self-portrait of Damián Domingo (1796-1834) by José Domingo Gabor, Oil on canvas
text_description: The Academia de Dibujo y Pintura, the first school for the visual arts, is founded by Damian Domingo. (Photo from Wikimedia Commons)
Coleccion de Trajes de Manila Y de Las Provincias, ca 1835, by Damian Domingo, depicts tipos del pais or types of Filipinos, based on class, race, and ethnicity, as seen in their costumes.

media_caption: Book cover of the illustrated edition of Flora de Filipinas, 1877
text_description: Fr Manuel Blanco’s Flora de Filipinas is first published with no illustrations. Later editions in 1877-1883 feature illustrations of the plants studied by Fr. Blanco, rendered by Filipino artists.
Escuela Superior de Pintura, Escultura y Grabado is established and will operate until 1898.
The subject of the earliest known photograph in the Philippines are the Tingguian of Abra, done in 1860.
The new mestizo elite commission portraits, landscapes, and bodegones for their houses called bahay na bato.

media_caption: The Parisian Life (French: Interior d'un Cafi) painting by Filipino painter and political activist Juan Luna
text_description: The style of impressionism is used by Juan Luna for The Parisian Life, 1892, a depiction of a lady sitting inside a café in Paris.
Paete sculptor Mariano Madrinan (in photo) wins critical acclaim in the Amsterdam Universal Exposition, by garnering the first prize for his Mater Dolorosa.

Local elites would patronize visual artists in the regions such as Juan Senson and Pedro Piñon of Angono, as well as the religious art of the santero and carroza making in Pampanga, through the works of Maximo Vicente and other santeros.

Un Indio Modelo is painted by Telesforo Sucgang, an anatomical study of a semi-nude brown-skinned male, posed inside a studio. It may also be considered as the continuity of the tipos del pais style of painting, employing academic principles of painting.
Hybrid images of precolonial letters and masonic emblems are used in the Katipunan flags, inspired by the masonic ideas of Andres Bonifacio.

media_caption: Temporary triumphal arch commemorating election of Emilio Aguinaldo as president of the Philippines, 1899.
text_description: Jan 23: A photograph of the celebration of the Republic of Malolos features a singkaban triumphal arch.

media_caption: Daet's Rizal monument, the first in the Philippines. 18 December 2007
text_description: Feb: The first Rizal Monument in the Philippines is completed at Daet, Camarines Norte. Photo: Rizal Monument in Daet, 2007 (Creative Commons)

media_caption: Exterior of the National Museum of Fine Arts facing Taft Avenue
media_credit: Photo by Mark Dela Cruz, courtesy of the National Museum
text_description: The National Museum, formerly called the Insular Museum of Ethnology, National History and Commerce, is founded. (Photo by Mark Dela Cruz)

media_caption: Group of Bontoc-Igorrotes 'Head-Hunters'. [Louisiana Purchase Exposition]. World's Fair Presentation Album 9, plate 641a.
text_description: Winners in the art competitions during the St. Louis Exposition are Felix Resurreccion Hidalgo, Fabian de la Rosa, Miguel Zaragoza, Vicente Rivera y Mir, Patricio Gaston O’Farrell, and Jorge Pineda.

Commercial lithographic printing flourishes, especially under the Carmelo and Bauermann Press, where prints for flyers, posters, waybills, and illustrations were produced. Jorge Pineda becomes the chief illustrator of Lipang Kalabaw, under the nom de plume Makahiya. (Photo from UP Diliman Main Library)

With the defeat of Philippine revolutionary forces, political cartoons are used by nationalists to continue fighting for the ideology of freedom. The image of Juan de la Cruz published in Lipang Kalabaw serves as the symbol of the suffering Filipino.
The modernist style of Victorio Edades, Hernando Ocampo, Ramon Estella, Vicente Manansala, Victor Oteyza, Cesar Legaspi, and Romeo Tabuena move towards abstraction.

article_title: VA 1908-1938 Pineda and Amorsolo, Manila Carnival
text_description: Jorge Pineda and Fernando Amorsolo are commissioned to design posters for the Manila Carnival.

Juan Abelardo, Ramon Peralta, Toribio Antillon, and Emilio Alvero are commissioned to paint scenography in the interior walls and ceilings of prominent houses in Manila and Bulacan. In Cebu and Bohol, Raymundo Francia, and Canuto Avila, decorate church ceilings in 1920-1941.
Francesco Monti designs the sculptural elements of the Metropolitan Theater, 1931, using Art Deco designs to complement the architectural designs of Juan Arellano.
In the 1930s, furniture design, such as Juan Nakpil’s Ambassador Chair for Puyat & Sons, fashion, and industrial design are influenced by art deco.

media_caption: The Sketch, The Artist and His Model, Victorio Edades, 1928
media_credit: Photo from National Museum of the Philippines Collection
text_description: Victorio Edades mounts an exhibition at the Philippine Columbian Club, espousing modernism in art, with works such as The Builders and The Sketch (in photo).

media_caption: Covers of the revised edition of Books 3 and 5 of Osias's The Philippine Readers published in 1932, the books measuring 14 cm. x 19 cm.
text_description: Fernando Amorsolo and Pablo Amorsolo serve as illustrators to the Philippine Reader series, and will influence the construction of the idealized way of life set in the countryside.

Victorio Edades forms the Triumvirate, composed of himself, Galo B. Ocampo, and Carlos V. Francisco, to execute mural commissions using an Art Deco/Modernist style for projects by Juan Nakpil. They work on murals in public spaces, such as theaters and hospitals.

Debates between Conservatives, represented by Ariston Estrada, and the Moderns, through Victorio Edades, Galo Ocampo, Hernando R. Ocampo, Salvador Lopez, and Francisco Arcellana, are published in various weekly journals and newsletters, centering on issues of aesthetics and art history.
Artists who explore abstract expressionism include Constancio Bernardo, Cenon Rivera, Arturo Luz, Victor Oteyza, Fernando Zobel, Federico Alcuaz, and Lee Aguinaldo.

media_caption: A beaming Manuel L. Quezon, taken shortly after his inauguration as President of the Commonwealth of the Philippines. Note the embroidery on his barong—the Philippine and American flags, and ribbons bearing the words Tydings-McDuffie.
text_description: Pres Manuel Quezon elevates the barong tagalog as the national male costume, with he himself wearing it as President of the new Commonwealth of the Philippines. (Photo from Presidential Museum and Library)
Fashion designer Ramon Valera combines the baro and saya into one gown as women’s wear.
Fernando Amorsolo paints the official portrait of President Quezon, as well as portraits of other major figures like US Resident Commissioner Paul McNutt and Executive Secretary Jorge Vargas.
Aug 22: The Cebu Arts Association is formed led by Julian N. Jumalon along with Oscar Figuracion, Ricardo Avila, Fidel Araneta, Silvestre Orfelia, Emilio Olmos, and Jose Trinidad Alcoseba.
Jun 15: The Atelier of Modern Art is founded under Victorio C. Edades, Diosdado M. Lorenzo, and Galo B. Ocampo.

Victorio Edades declares the existence of the Thirteen Moderns of Philippine art: Edades, Galo B. Ocampo, Diosdado Lorenzo, “Carlos Botong” Francisco, Vicente Manansala, Hernando R. Ocampo, Cesar Legaspi, Demetrio Diego, Jose Pardo, Ricarte Purugganan, Bonifacio Cristobal, Arsenio Capili, and Anita Magsaysay-Ho.
Art In Tagala, based on the Aurelio Alvero collection, is published.
Carlos "Botong" Francisco and other artists paint backdrops for stage plays and billboard ads.
Fernando Amorsolo paints commissioned portraits and landscape paintings for Jorge B. Vargas, such as Harvest Scene and Fishing Scene, 1942.
Reconstruction and Rehabilitation, 1943, by Gregorio Sibug depicts workers setting up the foundation of a new house as symbolism for starting anew out of the ashes of the war.
Paintings by Filipino Artists, featuring the art collection of Jorge B. Vargas, is published.
Priceless artworks in the museums, churches and homes of Intramuros are destroyed.
Fernando Amorsolo records war scenes such as Rizal Avenue on Fire, Ruins of the Manila Cathedral, and San Sebastian Church through Quiapo Ruins, all in 1945.
Liborio Gatbonton comes out with a comic strip called Jappy Days making fun of the Japanese in the most acerbic and inflammatory tone.
The Conservative vs. Modernist debate between Edades and Tolentino is rekindled in magazines published in July 1948.

The Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) is launched in 1948. Annual and semi-annual competitions begin with the first winners: Carlos “Botong” Francisco, first prize for Kaingin; Demetrio Diego, second prize for Capas; Vicente Manansala, third prize for Banaklaot; Cesar Legaspi, fourth prize for Sick Child; Diosdado Lorenzo, fifth prize for Japanese Inhumanities; H.R. Ocampo, sixth prize for Nude with Candle and Flower.
The AAP sponsors the First Neo-Realist exhibition as support for modern art.

article_title: VA 1951 Shell National Students Art Competition
text_description: The Shell National Students Art Competition is launched. Among its awardees from 1956 to 1965 are Joya, Alcuaz, Ang Kiukok, Ong Bun Gian, Manuel Rodriguez Jr, Veronica Lim (Yuyitung), and James Ong Le Pho. The award was halted during the 1970s and was later revived in 1989.

Philippine Art Gallery (PAG) puts up The First Exhibition of Non-Objective Art as support for modern art. PAG also facilitates the first effort to break through the international art scene through an exhibition of paintings and sculptures of 21 artists, which travels to New York and Washington in 1953-1954.
Aurelio S. Alvero, who used the pseudonym Magtanggol Asa, writes the monograph of The First Exhibition of Non-Objective Art in Tagala.

Conservative artists walk out of the Art Association of the Philippines (AAP) contests as protest to the perceived bias of the jury in awarding all the Rotary Club Golden Anniversary awards to modernists Galo Ocampo, Manuel Rodriguez Sr, and Vicente Manansala.
Art of the Philippines 1521-1957, edited by Winfield Scott Smith III, is published.
Manuel Rodriguez Sr launches the Contemporary Art Gallery which definitively opens up the art world to printmaking.

The first solo exhibition by Abdulmari Asia Imao is held in 1960 at the Contemporary Art Gallery in Mabini. His work explores Islamic motifs such as the sarimanok, okir, and Arabic calligraphy as idiom for his works.
The second generation modernists such as Jose Joya, Ang Kiukok, Mauro Malang Santos, Antonio Austria, Angelito Antonio, and Juvenal Sanso rise to prominence.
Roberto Chabet’s first exhibit is at the Luz Gallery, ushering in conceptual art in the Philippines.
The first solo exhibition of Federico Alcuaz, known for his tapestries and abstract paintings, is held.
Jaime Zobel de Ayala publishes Philippine Religious Imagery, a survey of Spanish colonial religious culture based on extensive private collections.
The Philippines participates in the 32nd International Art Exhibition of the Venice Biennale 1964. Jose Joya and Napoleon Abueva are chosen to represent the country.
Art in the Philippines by Dominador Castañeda is published.
Philippine Art Educators Association (PAEA) is founded, under the leadership of artists Araceli Dans and Brenda Fajardo. (Photo from Orlando Abon)
The Printmakers Association of the Philippines (PAP) is founded, under the leadership of Manuel Rodriguez Sr.
During the inauguration of the CCP, David Medalla stages a protest with the poet Jun Lansang and the visual artist Mars Galang inside the building itself.

Under Roberto Chabet as the first Museum Director and later Raymundo Albano as Visual Arts Director, the CCP Museum opens its exhibition programming to works influenced by the western avant-garde and conceptual tenets, pop art, happenings, environmental assemblages, new realism, performance art, and sound works.

article_title: VA 1969 PAP 1st annual graphic arts competition
text_description: Philippine Association of Printmakers holds its first annual national graphic arts competition where Manuel Rodriguez Jr wins.

The First CCP Thirteen Artists Award is given to Raymundo Albano, Angelito Antonio, Virgilio Aviado, Eduardo Castrillo, Benedicto Cabrera, Restituto Embuscado, Marciano Galang, Lamberto Hechanova, Jaime de Guzman, Noel Manalo, Ben Maramag, Manuel Rodriguez Jr, and Antonio Austria.

The exhibit Illumination at the CCP is considered the first sound art exhibit in a gallery setting, organized by the collaborative group Liwayway Recapping Co., composed of Roberto Chabet, Ray Albano, and Boy Perez.
The Nagkakaisang Progresibong Artista-Arkitekto (NPAA) is founded, advocating the tenets of social realism and protest art.

Protest art develops during the martial law period in the form of comics, murals, posters, drawings and illustrations for books, papier-mâché effigies, prints in etching, aquatint or rubbercut, photography, peryodikits (instant posters pasted on walls), masks, t-shirt printing, and even pendants and greeting cards as vehicles for political messages.
The first National Artist award is posthumously given to Fernando Amorsolo.

article_title: VA 1972 Francisco and Tolentino's National Artist awards
text_description: Carlos “Botong” Francisco (Photo 1) and Guillermo Tolentino (Photo 2) receive the National Artist award.
Ray Albano’s Step on the Sand and Make Footprints is critically received at the International Biennial Exhibition of Prints in Tokyo.

article_title: VA 1974 The Struggle for Philippine Art publication
text_description: Publication of The Struggle for Philippine Art by Purita Kalaw Ledesma and Amadis Ma. Guerrero strengthens the discourse on modern art in the Philippines.
Beyond Art, written and designed by Rodolfo Paras-Perez, demonstrates the many imaginative possibilities of book design.

Artist-run spaces serve as alternative venues of art practice, such as Gallery 7, Sanctuary, Gallery Indigo, the short-lived Shop 6 in Cubao, and one of the stalls of the Kamalig arcade in Manila, where artists experiment with various materials and provide critical views on the political situation of the country.

article_title: VA 1974 Shows in situ or streets
text_description: A growing impulse to mount shows away from institutional centers manifests in both protest art done in situ or on the streets and communities.
Ramon Orlina conducts his first exhibit Reflections, using glass as his medium for sculptural work.

article_title: VA 1976 Edades, Abueva receive National Artist award
text_description: Victorio Edades (Photo 1) and Napoleon Abueva (Photo 2) receive the National Artist award.

article_title: VA 1976 Metropolitan Museum of Manila founded
text_description: The Metropolitan Museum of Manila is founded to serve as exhibition venue for international art, while the Museum of Philippine Art is founded to show local work. Photo: Facade of Metropolitan Museum of Manila, 2018 (Photo by Kiko del Rosario)
Kulay-Anyo ng Lahi mural project is launched in Metro Manila by the government as part of its beautification campaign to boost tourism.

Kaisahan is formed, an art collective employing social realism with members Pablo Baens Santos, Edgar Talusan Fernandez, Renato Habulan, Antipas Delotavo, Papo de Asis, Albert Jimenez, and Jose Cuaresma. Photo: Renato Habulan, Pablo Baens Santos, and Antipas Delotavo, 2018 (Photo from Philstar)
A Heritage of Saints by Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton is published.
The Mobil Art Awards starts with its first batch of winners: Jose Joya, Danilo Dalena, Ang Kiukok, Romulo Olazo, and Mauro Malang Santos.
The Filipino Engraving is written by Jesus Merino OP, Rod Paras-Perez, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya.

Pamilya Pintura, a regional art group based in Bacolod, is formed. Its members include Nunelucio Alvarado, Charlie Co, Perry Argel, Jojo Regollo, Danny Dojillo, Norberto Roldan, Norberto Tarroja, Dennis Ascalon, Diokno Pasilan, and Boy Garovillo. (Photo courtesy of VIVA EXCON Community Archive)
Vicente Manansala receives the National Artist award.
The Central Bank publishes one volume of its Kayamanan series on its painting collection, written by Emmanuel Torres.

article_title: VA 1981 People and Art of the Philippines
text_description: People and Art of the Philippines is published in connection with an exhibit held at the Museum of Cultural History of the University of California in Los Angeles, with text by Gabriel Casal OSB, Regalado Trota Jose, and others.
Leonidas Benesa’s Okir is published, focusing on printmaking and its link with indigenous wood carving. (Photo from Kiko del Rosario)

article_title: VA 1983 Philippine Religious Carvings in Ivory
text_description: Philippine Religious Carvings in Ivory by Esperanza Bunag-Gatbonton is published.

The First Metrobank Annual Painting Competition opens. The winners in the mixed media category from 1984 to 1987 are Dindo Peralta, Raymon Maliwat, Alwin Reamillo, Nelson E. Ferraris, Noel El Farol, Manuel K. Tan, Gabriel Barredo, Angelito L. Lopez, Arnaldo B. Mirasol, Joel Marayag Ferrer, and Roberto Feleo.
Pinaglabanan Galleries (1984-1989), where artists and curators produce experimental art shows, opens in San Juan.

article_title: VA 1986 Biennale Prize awarded to Maestro
text_description: Lani Maestro is awarded the Biennale Prize at the second Havana Biennale for The Dark Depths, an installation consisting of electrical cables, broken glass, and black tar paper with written comments on torture victims.

The Black Artists of Asia (BAA) is organized in Bacolod by artists Nunelucio Alvarado, Peewee Roldan, Charlie Co, Dennis Ascalon, and Lourdes Villanueva. The BAA will later spearhead the Visayan Island Visual Art Exhibition and Conference (VIVA ExCon) in 1990 together with the CCP. (Photo from VIVA ExCon Community Archive)

article_title: VA 1986 Fight for the People's Right to Know
text_description: Emmanuel Gutierrez paints the mural Fight for the People’s Right to Know, Fight for Press Freedom in homage to the martyrs who fought the Marcos dictatorship: Macli-ing Dulag, Dr Bobby de la Paz, Edgar Jopson, Dr Johnny Escandor, and Ninoy Aquino. Gutierrez himself is later killed in a military encounter.
The Lakaran project of Rene Aquitania starts from Manila to Baguio, with the artist picking and collecting objects along his path. (Photo by Katrin De Guia)

article_title: VA 1986 Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces
text_description: The Ministry of Education, Culture and Sports publishes A Portfolio of 60 Philippine Art Masterpieces.
Robert Lane writes Philippine Basketry.
The exhibit Piglas, which features protest art, is shown at the CCP signaling a broadened artistic direction.

The Kababaihan sa Sining at Bagong Sibol na Kamalayan (Kasibulan), a feminist art organization is founded by visual artists Brenda Fajardo, Imelda Cajipe Endaya, Anna Fer, Ida Bugayong, and Julie Lluch. (Photo from Imelda Cajipe-Endaya)

article_title: VA 1987 Social Realism in the Philippines
text_description: Alice Guillermo writes Social Realism in the Philippines.
Arturo Luz receives the first Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
The works of Luna and Hidalgo are exhibited in Oro Plata at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.

Brenda Fajardo starts to paint the Baraha ng Buhay Pilipino aka Tarot Card series appropriating the images of the Babaylan (Shaman), Gaga (the Fool), Salamangkero (Magician), among others, to provide social commentary on Philippine society. (Photo by Rolando Codes)

The First Baguio Arts Festival is held. It helps to call attention to art from the regions and demonstrates the organizing skills of regional artists embarking on an international event. (Photo from Japan Foundation Manila and Baguio Arts Guild)

CCP launches the first seven monographs and videos on the seven arts edited by Nicanor Tiongson called the Tuklas Sining series. Twenty-one more videos and monographs will complete the 28-part series in 1994. A coffee-table book Tuklas Sining will collect and illustrate the first seven monographs in 1992.

First VIVA ExCon is held in Bacolod, led by Peewee Trinidad, Charlie Co, and Nune Alvarado, among others. In coordination with the CCP, it aims to formulate Visayan aesthetics from the different islands.
Cesar Legaspi receives the National Artist award. (Photo from Eileen Legaspi-Ramirez)
Jose Joya receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Traditional woodcarvers in Pampanga are affected by dislocation after the eruption and the long-term effect of the lahar flow. Contemporary potters experiment in creating pottery using lahar.

Sculpture in the Philippines: From Anito to Assemblage and Other Essays is written by Alice Guillermo and others, in conjunction with a retrospective of Philippine painting and sculpture at the Metropolitan Museum of Manila.
Bencab receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Artist-volunteers are recruited into the Visual Art committees of NCCA and a series of regional and national congresses begin.
Tony Velasquez receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
Crucible Workshop publishes Art Philippines, edited by Juan T. Gatbonton, Jeannie E. Javelosa, and Lourdes Ruth R. Roa.
Monumental public sculptures are created by Eduardo Castrillo, exemplified by the People Power Monument in White Plains, Quezon City..
The first Philippine Artists Awards (PAA) is held; it will later be supported by Philip Morris.

The CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art is published, edited by Nicanor G. Tiongson, with one whole volume dedicated to the Visual Arts, edited by Imelda Cajipe-Endaya, Alice Guillermo, and Santiago Pilar.
Malang Santos receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. Photo: The artist in his studion in Quezon City, 2003 (Photo from Soler Santos)

The First Sungdu-an National Visual Art Exhibition is held with curators Bobi Valenzuela, Virgilio Aviado, and Imelda Cajipe-Endaya aiming to provide a platform for artists and curators from the regions.
The National Museum publishes Faces from Maitum: The Archaeological Excavation of Ayub Cave, authored by Eusebio Dizon and Rey Santiago and edited by Esperanza Bunag Gatbonton.
Arturo Luz receives the National Artist award.

article_title: VA 1998 Discovering Philippine Art in Spain
text_description: Discovering Philippine Art in Spain is published to commemorate the centennial celebration of the proclamation of Philippine independence. It has essays on ethnological art, Islamic art, and secular art, written by Jose Maria Cariño, Felice Sta. Maria, Brenda Fajardo, Abraham Sakili, Regalado Trota Jose, and Santiago Pilar.

Artist-run space and collective Surrounded By Water (SBW) is established by Wire Tuazon and includes members Mike Adrao, Victor Balanon, Argie Bandoy, Jonathan Ching, Mariano Ching, Lena Cobangbang, Louie Cordero, Christina Dy, Lyra Garcellano, Nona Garcia, Geraldine Javier, Gary Ross Pastrana, and Lakay Ranjo.
J. Elizalde Navarro receives the National Artist award.

article_title: VA 2000 Garcia wins Philip Morris award
text_description: Nona Garcia wins the Grand Prize in the Philip Morris Group of Companies ASEAN Art Awards in Singapore and the Juror's Choice distinction in the Philip Morris Philippine Art Awards for the painting See Saw.
Ang Kiukok receives the National Artist award.
Jaime Laya publishes Letras y Figuras: Business in Culture, Culture in Business. (Photo from Anvil Publishing, Inc)
Tupada Action and Media Art (TAMA) or TUPADA is founded, composed of young artists interested in performance art in public spaces.
Flaudette May Datuin writes Home Body Memory: Filipina Artists in the Visual Arts, 19th Century to the Present. (Photo from UP Press)
Jose Joya receives the National Artist award.

Abraham Sakili’s Space and Identity: Expressions in the Culture, Art and Society of the Muslims in the Philippines is published, exploring the contribution of Islamic belief and Southeast Asian links to the traditional art of the Muslim Filipino.
The first Ateneo Art Awards competition is launched. The first awardees are Louie Cordero, Geraldine Javier, and Jayson Oliveria.

The Gawad Manlilikha ng Bayan is awarded to Darhata Sawabi (Photo 1) for Tausug pis syabit weaving, Haja Amina Appi for Sama mat weaving, and Eduardo Mutuc (Photo 2) for silversmithing or pukpuk. (Photos by Renato S. Rastrollo, NCCA)
Santiago Bose posthumously receives the Gawad CCP para sa Sining. (Photo by Wig Tysmans)
Ginto: History Wrought in Gold by Ramon Villegas is published based on the collection of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP). (Photo from BSP)
Ramon Valera is proclaimed National Artist for Fashion Design for his work on the Filipino terno.
The Constantino Foundation commissions the Tutok artist collective to create two murals that commemorate the heroism of Macario Sakay and Lean Alejandro.
Museum of Contemporary Art and Design Manila is launched at the College of Saint Benilde.
The First Manila Art Fair is organized.
Francisco Coching and Pitoy Moreno (in photo) are awarded the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.
The first Fete dela Wsk exhibit sound art is held.
Federico Alcuaz receives the National Artist award.
Elmer Nocheseda’s Palaspas is published.
Philippine Ancestral Gold is published by the Ayala Foundation, authored by Florina Capistrano-Baker, John Guy, and John Miksic.

Bastards of Misrepresentation is curated by Manuel Ocampo in Hong Kong. It showcases the diverse practices explored by Filipino avant-garde artists like Poklong Anading, Yason Banal, Argie Bandoy, Bea Camacho, Lena Cobangbang, Romeo Lee, Pow Martinez, Louie Cordero, Carlo Ricafort, Gerardo Tan, MM Yu, and Maria-Jeona Zoleta.

article_title: VA 2012 Edades: From Freedom to Fruition
text_description: The book Edades: From Freedom to Fruition is published in conjunction with the retrospective exhibition on National Artist Victorio Edades at the CCP.
Art Fair Philippines is founded.
Francisco Coching receives the National Artist award.

article_title: VA 2014, Metrobank Foundation Alice Guillermo Award for Art Criticism
text_description: The Metrobank Foundation Alice Guillermo Award for Art Criticism is instituted.

article_title: VA 2014 Purita Kalaw Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism
text_description: The Purita Kalaw Ledesma Prize for Art Criticism is instituted by the Ateneo Art Gallery and the Kalaw Ledesma Foundation Inc.

article_title: VA 2014 Journey of a Thousand Shuttles
text_description: Journey of a Thousand Shuttles by Norma Respicio is published.

article_title: VA 2015 Chabet, Talaandig, Farrales, Gawad CCP
text_description: Roberto Chabet, the Talaandig School for Living Traditions, and Ben Farrales receive the Gawad CCP para sa Sining.

The Philippines participates again in the 56th Venice Biennale, with a team made up of curator Patrick Flores, artists Manny Montelibano, Roberto Chabet, and Jose Tence Ruiz under a curatorial platform Tie a String Around the World, featuring the work of Manuel Conde and Carlos “Botong” Francisco.
